content.description:
I'm pretty confident this hadn't yet been climbed... It was very dirty when i found it and no an obvious line... 

  Start sitting in the dark corner underclinging the crack above you with your feet on the face in front... layback and kneebar (if you like) to gain a nice undercling pocket... Get another hold on the boulder that was over your head and find your way right to gain a cool moderate top out...
content.location: in the back of the alcove to the left of Mrs. Lovett, up the hill...

content.description:
A nice lowball that never gets done but i like it better than the Arrow which is right around the corner at a similar grade... 

  Sit at a couple of good start crimps with one good foot and throw right for the arete... Bump that hand then top it out with ease...
content.location: On top of Overlooked and to the left... Say you top out Overlooked and your all "I want to keep climbing"... Well just walk 5 paces to your left and have a seat at this lil bugger....

content.description:
An interesting one-mover problem with a neat pocket for the start.  

  Start with the little mono-pocket (it's possible to stack fingers in it, or get a thumb catch and turn it into a pocket-pinch), and the slopey crimp just to the right. Find some feet, pull off the ground and make either an outrageous throw around the mini-roof to the top or go to the lip of the roof then bump to the top. Either way your feet will probably cut at some point. Match and top out.  

  There used to be a better crimp but it has broken.
content.location: From the start of Overlooked, look down and to the right and you should see a mini-roof (that's great for doing pull-ups) and a little pocket beneath the roof. The pocket is where this starts.

content.description: This one starts with the first few moves of Only a Cardinal but continues traversing the slightly sloping lip leftwards... This makes the route so much more fun and the top out a little more moderate so i dont think the extra length changes the grade... Top out at the same spot as for Welcome to the grave...
content.location: start as for Only a Cardinal and finish as for Welcome to the grave... In the alcove left of Mrs. Lovett...

content.description:
another worth while addition to the growing area... This is turning out to be a moderate climbers/warm up sanctuary... 

  This problem would be v1 if the starting hold    weren't so crimpy and or if there were any feet worth a damn under the roof... I decided to call it v2 cause you start by hanging full weight off of a small crimp and either throwing the upside down heel or a powerful campus move to the sloping lip... Once at the lip its more like v1ish as you press up on to the slab and smear your way up the easy but blank slab above...
content.location: Between Shadows,Everywhere and Mrs. Lovett there is a long low roof, this problem climbs the middle of this section up the clean streak...

content.description:
This line is much like Fleet Street (v3) but a little cleaner and less spooky... I cleaned out a few stubborn chock stones to make the OW work... It may have been climbed before as it was cleaner than the rest of the rock (but not clean by a long shot) but never the way it goes now since i removed the stones from the crack... 

  I think more people will like this than Fleet Street... Give it a try... 

  There are, im sure, many ways to do it but i went with the same beta as Fleet Street For the most part with a few changes... I start laying back the off width with feet on the wall in front of me (you dont get to start laying down on this one), then stuff my legs in the crack and make a few moves to the right... Gain a crimp with the right hand and move your legs to get a knee bar... You can lean out left and work the knee bar up till you are able to stand in the corner... Up the corner above to the top (Same top as Pirelli's Purse (v1+)...
content.location: to the left of Fleet Street look for a clean Off Width roof...

content.description:
This one may have been climbed before but i cleaned a good bit of moss off of it... I have only done the stand start which was fun but not too challenging... The sit start will go at a much harder grade and will be more fun i think... 

  Climb the middle of the slab/low angle face avoiding the escape to the arete out right... delicate climbing on tiny holds...
content.location: If you are facing the Mrs. Lovett cave turn around and the problem climbs the middle of the slab in front of you...

content.description:
The starting hold just begs to be used so i cleaned up a bit and its pretty fun... It does share a few holds with Shadows,Everywhere but it has its own line for sure... 

  Start hanging on a hold in a scoop 5 feet left of Shadows,Everywhere (v3)... Throw a heel (as there are no good feet under the roof) or campus the first move... Then mantel on to the slab and climb to the top staying left of the crack...
content.location: 5 feet left of the wide Crack on Shadows,Everywhere look for a nice obvious starting hold at the lip of the roof...

content.description:
Sit Start on a good edge and pick which of the many feet are possible and make a tough toss to the lip. Then top out. 

  This is a route that I found with chalk already on it. I dont know if it already goes by another name but let me know if it does and Ill be happy to change it.
content.location: Up the hill from overlooked in the alcove located between Only A Cardinal and Welcome to the Grave.

content.description:
A variation to one of the best climbs in the park. Very core intensive, and a slight mental challenge. This line features some incredible movement and should see more traffic. 

  Start as for "Overlooked" and match the lip via some heel-toe cams. Instead of going up to the crack, traverse right on the lip and get to the arete.   Find some good holds and take the foot cams out and core up!    Get a left heel cam on the lip and keep going up the arete with the left hand until you get to a good hold.    From here release the heel cam. Hold the swing over a poor landing and make a very committing move to a jug at the lip.   Next, keep it together and figure out how to top out on good holds. 

  Really good, might be a classic.
content.location: Trailside Boulders.

content.description:
After bouldering all across the country this remains perhaps my very favorite problem. It is both technical and powerful and involves a greater variety of holds and movements than most boulders.

An amazing boulder problem involving crazy beta and full body fitness. Start under the lowest roof in the back of the cave on two hueco pockets in the roof with fairly poor feet but they are there. A few choices here but most people end up in a bat-hang in the wide crack then switch to a heel-toe-cam and make a cool move to the lip of the roof. The holds at the lip seem bad but feel good when you are on them. Sink your fingers in to the crack and pull the last crux getting out from under the roof to better holds and the top.

A really fun climb. Beta intensive.
content.protection: have a good spotter and a few pads...
content.location:
the nice roof facing the marsh...

(43.1186, -71.1802)

content.description:
This one is only 2 or 3 moves long... 

  Start sitting or squating on OK holds and make one or two powerful moves to a sloping hold above move a little left and throw a heel to mantel...
content.location: the arete just left of the finish of Mrs. Lovett... At the mouth of an alcove...

content.description:
I cleaned this line out from under tons of dirt, and small plant life not really knowing how well it would climb... i was very happy with the outcome... 

  The problem climbs right to left along the lip of a cave following a series of different holds, heelhooks and fun moves to a nice top out right before you run in to a tree... 

  maybe a hard lower start could be done but this start works fine for me... try it and suggest a grade... 

  Video link... Check it out! 

youtube.com/watch?v=bEvl9wH…
content.location: from the top of overlooked scramble up over a boulder or two and you will see the cave... start at an obvious hold close to a large tree and climb left to a medium tree...

content.description:
This is really just a direct finish to Mrs. Lovett... Note quite as much fun as that route but still good... I found it to be a little harder... 

  After the first big move to a good hold top out straight up eventually gaining a good hold out right... 

  Again climb it and suggest a grade...
content.location: from the top of overlooked scramble over boulders till you see the cave... start hanging at the good hold by the big tree and climb up and slightly left to the top...

content.description:
Sit start with hands on a good flat ledge... Mantel up and climb on easy crimps up the arete and top out...  

  A good beginner route other than the landing... Pads and spotters should make it safe...
content.location: 20 feet to the right of overlooked and set back 10 feet or so from the trail... Look for a chimney like feature, this line climbs the prow on the left side of the chimney... see photo...

content.description:
If you really like lowball boulder problems you will love this one... Otherwise you need not try it... 

  Sit On the ground at a good crimp in the left hand and a little something in the right heel out left... Mantel with a couple of bumps with the left hand... 

  I thought it was pretty fun if a bit short (understatement)...
content.protection: 1 pad, 2 pads would be cheating cause you'd be halfway through the problem, haha...
content.location: Standing on top of overlooked looking away from the marsh there is an opening between 2 boulders, on the left is Trailside v1 on the right is this little number...

content.description:
A great low ball mantel problem... It ended up being way cooler than i thought it would be...  

  Basically you start sitting with your choice of slopers and a few crimps... i went more right but you can do what works for you... mantel up and grab the arete and run up the slab...  

  do it... solid rock solid moves... 

  Here is a little video of the first ascent... 

youtube.com/watch?v=wED-3ZL…
content.location: From the top of overlooked look away from the pond and this problem sits atop another boulder facing you... see photos...

content.description:
An absolute banger. Start with hands in the obvious horizontal crack and smear feet, make a big move to the jug on the lip. It is possible to dead point, but for style points go for a 3 points off dyno. Cross right hand onto a sloppy jug and move right and left hand out to sloppy crimps. Throw up a heal and rock over into a committing move to a sloppy crack (watch out for the small tree), the rest of the top out is easy, but don't fall. 

  The top out of this route needs to be further cleaned, still very doable but it definitely gets sketchy 

This was formally named "Pretty girls with poor eye contact"
content.location: Directly about 50m behind "overlooked" on the obvious overhung face

content.description:
Starts with one hand on either side of the trapezoid shaped rock, then follow up on to the boulder above it using the arete, and ticked hold for right hand, stick right foot out and top out is cake.  

Rock did not look clean and there were no chalk marks, but if this route goes by another name or already exists please edit*
content.location: Just to the left of Overlooked, starts at trapezoid shaped rock

content.description:
Careful on this one... A bit heady with its crux at the top... I do need to clean it a little more but its good to go for sure... 

  Start off the chockstone in the chimney climbing the 15 foot wall above to a smooth top out... DONT FALL...
content.location: A little tricky to locate... Scamper up the alcove left of Mrs. Lovett and up hill a little... climb up in the back at the tree above Welcome to the grave... Walk about 15-20 feet and look for a chimney on your right... Go in to the chimney and stand on a chalk stone... Avoiding the wall behind you climb the left (higher) wall to a crux at the top and a good mantel... Both the crux and the mantel would be no big deal if not for the nasty chimney below...

content.description:
This is the problem I've been looking for... I love the idea of off-width roof climbing but never tryed one... It also has kneebars and hand jams, its no wonder it went so long without being climbed, haha... 

  Start in the back of the cave as far as you can manage... Lay on your back and stick your feet up the crack... Do a sit up layback the edge with your hands and try to keep your back off the ground (its very low)... Scoot right like this till you can stick a kneebar and then a good hand jam... Get a nice stem rest before finishing up the hand crack above... the position is such that if you are not a solid crack climber you might be sketched... 

  I cleaned some chossy rock out and lots of spider webs... i still need to clean the top off a little better but its pretty much good to go... 

  follow the crack back down and right to get off... 

  id love to hear you opinion of the grade since ive never climbed this style problem before...
content.location: If you are on top of overlooked looking away from the pond this route is at about the 2 oclock (you know, slightly to the right) position about 50ft up the hill... If you know where you are looking you can see the top out...

content.description:
Start on two sidepulls with a high foot and make a big move out of the roof to the lip.  

  The top out is more moderate. Don't blow it or you have to do that HARD first move all over again.
content.location: To the left of Chunk O' Blitz.

content.description:
This one is often lost in the shadow of it's famous brother Overlooked (v4). Even though we always have time to take another lap on one of the best problems in the park (or world) it can take a while to get curious about the other lines in the same area. 

  A pretty fun climb provided you have the requisite reach. The first move is rather large and might just be a show stopper if V6 is anywhere near your limit.   

  After the big initial undercling move navigate a crimp or two, a cool sloper move then find your way to the top.  

  Take care with pad placement cause the landing zone isn't perfect.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter are helpful as the landing zone is between a tree and a funky rock.
content.location: 20 feet to the left of overlooked there is a large tree. This problem starts just right of the tree.

content.description:
Terrible slopers and difficult compression moves make this the most difficult problem in the Trailside Boulders.  Sit start with the left arete and a sidepull for the right hand.  Pull off the ground, then slap and squeeze your way up the aretes to reach a sloping jug and an easier topout.

 This problem seems to keep breaking and is affectionately known to some as "Chunk O Shitz".
content.location: When following the trail through the boulders from Boulder Natural, most people have to duck through the cave that this problem helps form.  This climbs the overhanging blunt arete to the left of The Arrow and right of the roof that is Dome Piece .

content.description:
Stand start with a shallow incut flake for the right hand about six inches below the lip of the roof. Grab a lower gaston crimp for the left hand and pick from a choice of footholds. Bare down hard on that right hand and pull on to the wall. Make a big and committing move out left to a positive dish that will allow for the proper compression in order to hold the foot-cut.

 Once on this dish, figure out how to match hands and then execute the same press/ mantle as for "Dome Piece".
content.protection: 3 or 4 pads and a spotter or two.
content.location: This boulder problem starts a few feet to the right of Dave Graham's "Dome Piece". The landing is a bit scary. It feels as if a foot pop could throw you down to the start of "Chunk O' Blitz", or if the swing isn't held or a dry fire occurs, you will fall backward 6 feet onto the ground.  If you die, maybe you'll come back as a leotard.

content.description: this is a really fun little warm up for overlooked. on the same boulder as a V12, sit start down and right of a painted arrow on the rock. go hand over hand up the arete to the top. really really fun and a confidence booster for those who cant do overlooked
content.location: if your coming from boulder natural. it is one of the first boulders you see at trailside and has a white arrow painted on it.

content.description:
As you hike between Boulder Natural and Lower Slabs, there are a few boulders along the side of the trail with a few nice routes, the favorite being Overlooked (V4)....  There are a few moderates and a few super hard routes here as well.... A good place to go on a cold day to soak up the southern exposure.... It can get hot, hot, hot in the summer.... 

  UPTATE: Lots of new routes have been cleaned behind Overlooked... Most of the new routes are moderates from v1-v3... To get to them go over or around overlooked and climb over a boulder with a hand to fist sized crack in it... When you get over that you will see a cave where Mrs. Lovett v2+ is (my favorite new route here)... To the left of that is an alcove that houses a few cool routes like Shaving The Pope V2... and to the right you will find Fleet Street V3 and its brother Shadows, Everywhere v3... More to come for sure...
